body.p:
I am almost ashamed to address you in
reply to yours of such an early date, but, believe me
sir, it is from no want of regard for your kind attention
to me, neither is it from any disrespect to your correspon
dence, far from it, for, although personally unacquainted
yet, from the tenor of your letters, I feel satisfied, I could
too esteem you as a friend, and I have no doubt that
the reasons I assign for my delay, will be ample apology
for not replying to you at an earlier period, firstly,
I had to make preparations in my school for a public
& private examination, in which I am sure you
will sympathize with me, (I have sent you the whole
particulars for insertion in your Occident,) secondly,
though not least, I had to complete arrangements for
my union with Mr. Sarfaty's daughter, this completed
I will devote myself to your service. Should you feel
disposed to appoint me your Agent, I shall most
readily render my aid in order to forward your in-
terests, but I fear, as the state of things are, you must
not expect great progress, as to all appearance we
are in a fallen state, and very likely a just retribution
for the well known immorality practised here
Hebrew I hear of no other country with
so little hope of success as Jamaica, the veil of dispair
seems to overshadow us, and a gloom hovers over
us, threatening the approach of some impending
evil. I have been here about 9 years, but I have
not known things to bear such a fearful aspect
as at present, 'tis true it affects me little, but every
thing sooner or later must have its turn, and I fear
the future, I will at any rate do my best for you

let me know the state of your affairs in Jamaica,
and order to be handed over to me such Books
as you have in the possession of other persons, I obtained
a Subscriber for you, and would have obtained more, had
I been in possession of your authority, this was merely
in conversation with Mr. Phenias Bravo on your
letter to Mr. Jacobs, which was the gem of the day
in Jamaica, I went up at Sollas' my brother in law, to
operate at his child's bHebrew and he was delighted with
it, I think it a good incentive to your getting sub-
scribers, but you must know more or less that we
have very few literary characters here. I thank
you for the numbers you have sent me gratuitously

Miss Peixotto handed me your last
correspondence enclosed in hers, when she was ex-
ceedingly ill, and indeed not expected to live, she
has since recovered, and wrote a letter in reply
to yours but not living in Kingston she left it at
her brother's residence in Spanish Town, so
therefore she has been unable to address you by
this conveyance. I have taken the opportunity
of Mr. Hart's leaving for your part of the world
being a large communication and would have cost
you a little extra postage.

The financial condition of our
Synagogue is any thing but prosperous, my income
is about $800 by both departments Assistant Reader
& School master, which taking all things into
consideration I would resign tomorrow for the
same amt: either in England or America should
you hear of any thing you may let me know

I cannot write you at greater length at present
but will prepare something more lengthy next
opportunity. I have sent you enclosed a detailed
a/c of matters connected with the Jews in Jamaica
you may use it at pleasure with any addition
your better judgment may think fit to make
the a/c of the examination you will receive through
my father in law per Steamer. I therefore conclude
by wishing you all the success that mortals can
receive on earth, and that you may reap the
goodly fruits of your labour in this & the world
to come is the sincere wish
